I'm not sure I agree with this.  Shouldn't it be covered by the policy?  If an attester can only get a stale value and can't vouch for it not having been changed since, then putting that fact in the Evidence allows the verifier to make a decision appropriately.
+1, I agree with Dave, there may be other intermediate situations between simple trust and non-trust.

```suggestion
It is important to prevent old Evidence or old Attestation Results
that are no longer correct to be assessed as valid. Replay attacks
are an important reason to do that. More importantly, the validity
of Conceptual Messages, such as Evidence or Attestation Results,
is the basis for trustworthy remote attestation procedures, in general.
```
I feel that line 388 and 390 are duplicated.

```suggestion
state of the Attester, and/or the Appraisal Policy for Evidence,
```

```suggestion
Distributed handles are used in place of nonces for Evidence generation.
```

It seems like that the handle is also a nonce, and the difference is that this nonce is from a third party (a centralized entity), not the Verifier or Relying Party.
I'm afraid this approach is more complex because you need to consider the time sync among three entities. For example, the time of receiving the handle among different entities may be different, therefore the handle expired time will be different. If the handle on the Verifier expires earlier than the Attester, the handle may already be expired while Verifier receives the Evidence from Attester.
I think these new-added events had been questioned before, that the examples below don't use them.

```suggestion
This is essential in deciding whether the included Claims and their values can be considered fresh, meaning they still reflect the latest state of the Attester, and that any Attestation Result was generated using the latest Appraisal Policy for Evidence.
```

```suggestion
Freshness is a key component  for enabling caching and reuse of both Evidence and Attestation Results, which is especially valuable in cases where their computation uses a substantial part of the resource budget (e.g., energy in constrained devices).
```

```suggestion
Timestamps can also be added on a per-Claim basis if wanted, to allow distinguishing the time of creation of Evidence from the time that a specific Claim value was generated.
```

```suggestion
In this approach, a non-predictable nonce is sent by the remote entity, and the nonce is then signed and included along with the Claims in the Evidence or Attestation Result.
```

```suggestion
After the appraising entity checks that the sent and received nonces are the same, the appraising entity knows that the Claims were signed after the nonce was generated.
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
For example, if clocks exist and are considered trustworthy but are not synchronized, first a nonce-based exchange may be used to determine the (rough) time offset between the involved peers, followed by any number of timestamp based exchanges.
```

```suggestion
A second approach places the onus of timekeeping solely on the appraising entity (e.g., the Verifier for Evidence, or the Relying Party for an Attestation Result).
```

```suggestion
In this approach, a non-predictable nonce is generated by the appraising entity, and the nonce is then signed and included along with the Claims in the Evidence or Attestation Result.
```

```suggestion
After checking the sent and received nonces are the same, the appraising entity knows that the Claims were signed after the nonce was generated, effectively locking its clock to the produced payload.
```

```suggestion
After checking the sent and received nonces are the same, the appraising entity knows that the Claims were signed after the nonce was generated.
```

I don't think we should ditch this.

The essential premise is on line 869. In particular, by using "solely" I wanted to discuss the case where the only clock that the appraiser can trust is its own.  The intent of line 870 is just to illustrate two common instances where the appraiser can't rely on the peer's clock.

The overall premise for this whole paragraph is that appraiser does _not_ consider any time assertion made the peer, and to determine what kind of information can be used in this case to evaluate freshness.

Clearly, once the peer's clock becomes usable - as in the example at line 880 - then finer-grained timestamping can become input to the evaluation of the freshness policy as well.

Hopefully I have made my intention clear and the ambiguities in the existing text can be fixed accordingly :-)

Wei Pan was added to the author list but wasn't removed from the
Acknowledgements section at the time so now appears in both places.
This PR corrects that.

Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@ntdev.microsoft.com>
